instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible short <CHIP>U9400</CHIP>
threads.message: Hi ive got an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> that had a short on <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> with 0 volts when plugged in , i removed <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> and short went away , now ive replaced <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> and board powers to 19.6V then cycles off when it reaches 1.6a , under the thermal cam it shows <CHIP>U9580</CHIP> and <CHIP>U9400</CHIP> getting very hot so im guessing i have a duff <CHIP>U9400</CHIP> , question is . Is it possible to replace this one the load a new os or would i have to replace them all or is this just now a dead board ?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> possible short <CHIP>U9400</CHIP>
threads.message:
Compare diode mode to ground readings at L9080/580.
If <CHIP>U9400</CHIP> NAND is fried, bad news.
You need to replace all NAND chips and there is lot of work to do.
